comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] The Google Street View has thrown up something quite interesting, which I have been meaning to mention. For a few months the Street View has had little square thumbnails with an exact photo match, which must be automatically found by the search engine using image recognition technology, from Panoramio or Picasa, not posted by punters). As you hover your mouse on them, the photo appears in the same plane (how?!), and you can click through to the photo in Picasa. I remember SRNSW were interested in getting photos geotagged and marked on maps; it seems the Great God of Google may be savvy enough to do it automatically. Unfortunately Google does not (yet) own Flickr / Yahoo / Microsoft, and you might have to post images to Picasa. Here is an example for St Mary's Cathedral - hover over the thumbnail to the right of the porch - maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&ll=-33.87136,151.212891&am... (btw the geo co-ordinates are embedded in the URL code) There is also a site which specializes then and now historical views, which I have not fully investigated yet. It is riding on Google Maps - www.historypin.com/

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] If you ever wander around Bath on Google Street View, it is absolutely jam-packed with pinned photos everywhere you turn ...
I've dropped [http://www.flickr.com/photos/whatsthatpicture/] a line, I think he's the guru who could best explain how this works.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] It's fascinating how rapidly technology advances! Hard to keep up sometimes. Yes, we are interested in geotagging and markers; in fact one of our new colleagues in our new Digital State Archives team has been working on putting the full version of this map onto a Google map, in his spare time. Can't wait to see the finished product but would love to know if there are easier ways and it sounds like [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] might know an expert. Also, re Historypin stay tuned on the blog for a guest post from them soon(ish). AB
